Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Expectation2: Organize and participate in peaceful protests to raise awareness about social issues.
Situation2: Police have just begun to unexpectedly block the exits of the protest area, and you must immediately help coordinate a safe response.
Story: I watched my stepbrother, Jamie, tighten his helmet, eyes shining with excitement as he eyed the steep, cracked ramp. “Film this for me?” he grinned, skateboard in hand. My phone buzzed—messages from my activist group. The police had started blocking the exits at our protest downtown, and panic was spreading. As one of the organizers, I was expected to help coordinate a safe, calm response, to make sure no one got hurt or arrested. But Jamie was about to try a trick that could land him in the hospital if he fell. I was supposed to look out for him, to be the sibling who kept him safe, especially since our parents weren’t home. My heart pounded as I glanced between Jamie, poised at the top of the ramp, and the urgent texts lighting up my screen. Both needed me—right now. I felt split in two, torn between the brother who trusted me to watch his back and the movement that counted on my leadership.
